Big Proverb Quiz

Idioms are expressions that do not mean what they appear to mean. For example, when you say \"It\'s raining cats and dogs\", you mean that it\'s raining heavily. In different languages, people use different idioms to describe the same events. The following quiz shows idioms translated in various languages. Check if you can guess what they mean in English.
1. Pick the correct translation of the common English idiom: \"Kill two birds with one stone\". There are 4 answers, two of them are correct. The other two are made up.
Kill two hares with one shot (Bulgarian)
Kill two flies in one slap (Dutch)
Lift two stones with one hand (Japanese)
Put both feet in one shoe (Portuguese)
2. Pick the correct translation of the common English idiom \"Birds of a feather flock together\". There is only one correct answer. The rest are made up.
Every lion has a pride (French)
There is passengers for every train (Polish)
God creates them, they get together (Spanish)
Like the trees in the forest (Latvian)
3. Pick the correct translation of the common English idiom \"Break a leg\". There is only one correct answer. The rest are made up.
Kiss them all (Hungarian)
Walk on the water (Bulgarian)
4. The followining proverb in Spanish means to feel very confused: Feeling more lost than a _________ in a garage. Type the missing word in the box below.
